meta.title: Linear Equations in Two Variables - Exercise 4.3 (Short Answer Questions)

questions.question: Draw the graph of the linear equation $3x + 4y = 6$. At what points, the graph cuts the x-axis and the y-axis?
questions.solution:
To draw the graph, we find points:

  • Put $x = 0$: $4y = 6 \Rightarrow y = 1.5$. Point $(0, 1.5)$.
  • Put $y = 0$: $3x = 6 \Rightarrow x = 2$. Point $(2, 0)$.

Plot these points and join them.

Cuts x-axis at $(2, 0)$.

Cuts y-axis at $(0, 1.5)$.

questions.question: Draw the graph of the linear equation $y = mx + c$ for $m = 2$ and $c = 1$. Read from the graph the value of $y$ when $x = \frac{3}{2}$.
questions.solution:
Equation: $y = 2x + 1$.

Points to plot:

  • $x=0, y=1 \Rightarrow (0, 1)$
  • $x=1, y=3 \Rightarrow (1, 3)$
  • $x=-1, y=-1 \Rightarrow (-1, -1)$

From the graph, when $x = \frac{3}{2} = 1.5$:

$y = 2(1.5) + 1 = 3 + 1 = 4$.

Value of y is 4.

questions.question: Draw the graph of the linear equation $2x + 3y = 12$. At what points, the graph cuts the x-axis and the y-axis?
questions.solution:
Points:

  • $x=0 \Rightarrow 3y=12 \Rightarrow y=4$. Point $(0, 4)$.
  • $y=0 \Rightarrow 2x=12 \Rightarrow x=6$. Point $(6, 0)$.

Cuts x-axis at $(6, 0)$.

Cuts y-axis at $(0, 4)$.

questions.question: Draw the graph of the linear equation $y = x$ and $y = -x$ on the same cartesian plane. What do you observe?
questions.solution:
Graph $y=x$: Passes through $(0,0), (1,1), (2,2)$.

Graph $y=-x$: Passes through $(0,0), (1,-1), (2,-2)$.

Observation: The two lines intersect at the origin $(0, 0)$ and are perpendicular to each other.

questions.question: Determine the point on the graph of the linear equation $2x + 5y = 19$, whose ordinate is $1\frac{1}{2}$ times its abscissa.
questions.solution:
Given: Ordinate ($y$) $= 1\frac{1}{2} \times$ Abscissa ($x$).

$y = \frac{3}{2}x$.

Substitute in equation:

$2x + 5(\frac{3}{2}x) = 19$

$2x + \frac{15x}{2} = 19$

$\frac{4x + 15x}{2} = 19 \Rightarrow 19x = 38 \Rightarrow x = 2$.

$y = \frac{3}{2}(2) = 3$.

The point is $(2, 3)$.

questions.question: Draw the graph of the equation represented by a straight line which is parallel to the x-axis and at a distance 3 units below it.
questions.solution:
A line parallel to the x-axis is of the form $y = k$.

Since it is 3 units below the x-axis, $y = -3$.

The graph is a horizontal line passing through $(0, -3)$.

questions.question: Draw the graph of the linear equation whose solutions are represented by the points having the sum of the coordinates as 10 units.
questions.solution:
Condition: Sum of coordinates $= 10$.

Equation: $x + y = 10$.

Points: $(0, 10), (10, 0), (5, 5)$.

Plot these points and join them to form the line.

questions.question: Write the linear equation such that each point on its graph has an ordinate 3 times its abscissa.
If the point $(3, 4)$ lies on the graph of the equation $3y = ax + 7$, find the value of $a$.
questions.solution:
Substitute $x=3, y=4$ in the equation:

$3(4) = a(3) + 7$

$12 = 3a + 7$

$3a = 5 \Rightarrow a = \frac{5}{3}$.

questions.question: How many solution(s) of the equation $2x + 1 = x - 3$ are there on the: (i) Number line (ii) Cartesian plane.
questions.solution:
Simplify the equation: $2x - x = -3 - 1 \Rightarrow x = -4$.

(i) Number line: It represents a unique point $x = -4$. So, one solution.

(ii) Cartesian plane: It represents the line $x = -4$ (parallel to y-axis). It has infinitely many solutions (e.g., $(-4, 0), (-4, 1), (-4, 2)...$).

questions.question: Find the solution of the linear equation $x + 2y = 8$ which represents a point on (i) x-axis (ii) y-axis.
questions.solution:
(i) On x-axis: y-coordinate is 0.

Put $y=0$: $x + 2(0) = 8 \Rightarrow x = 8$. Point: $(8, 0)$.

(ii) On y-axis: x-coordinate is 0.

Put $x=0$: $0 + 2y = 8 \Rightarrow y = 4$. Point: $(0, 4)$.

questions.question: Let $y$ varies directly as $x$. If $y = 12$ when $x = 4$, then write a linear equation. What is the value of $y$ when $x = 5$?
questions.solution:
Since $y \propto x$, we have $y = kx$.

Given $y=12$ when $x=4$: $12 = k(4) \Rightarrow k = 3$.

Linear Equation: $y = 3x$.

When $x = 5$: $y = 3(5) = 15$.
